chapters.title: Intro to State - need to hide output

lessons.title: a
lessons.interactiveContent:
Often, we need to remember certain things. Like how many times a button has been clicked.

We'll now learn about state, a special way in React to make components remember values.

lessons.title: a - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
To render JavaScript, we need an embedded expression.

Create an embedded expression inside the JSX paragraph and display the value 0 for now.

Make sure to pick {, followed by 0, and finally }.

lessons.title: a - Copy - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We use state to make React components remember values between renders, like tracking how many times a button has been clicked.

Import useState from the "react" package. As this is a named export, we use { } to specify which part we want to import.

Make sure to pick {, followed by useState, and finally }.

lessons.title: b
lessons.interactiveContent:
Defining state looks a bit funky. We use an array structure and put the name of the variable we want to use inside the array.

Make sure to pick const, followed by [count].

lessons.title: b - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Next, we assign a value with the useState function.

useState is a special function (called a hook) in React that allows components to remember and update values over time.

Make sure to pick =, followed by useState.

lessons.title: b - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We pass the initial value we want to set as argument to the useState function.

Pass 0 as the argument to the useState function.

Make sure to pick useState followed by ( and then 0, ).

lessons.title: b - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can now display the value, but not update it yet. We define a second array entry, setCount, to update a state.

This function is used specifically to change the value of count and trigger a re-render.

Make sure to pick count, followed by count.

lessons.title: b - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can use the setCount function to update the count variable automatically when we call the function and pass a new value as the argument.

Whenever setCount is called the count variable is updated and re-rendered. Try it: click the button!

Make sure to pick setCount, followed by setCount.

lessons.title: Lesson #10 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Call the setter function to increase the state variable points.

Make sure to pick setPoints.

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use the correct import statement to allow usage of state to track how many times a character in your favorite movie appears on screen.

Make sure to pick {, followed by useState, and finally }.

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does this code do?

Increases points by 2 each time the button is clickedDecreases points by 2 each time the button is clicked

Increases points by 2 each time the button is clicked.

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a counter that counts up every time the button is clicked.

Make sure to pick setClicks, followed by clicks, and finally + 1.

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which statement about the useState hook is true?

useState allows React components to remember values across rendersuseState can only hold string values

useState allows React components to remember values across renders.

lessons.title: Lesson #14
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a state variable and its corresponding setter function.

Make sure to pick points, followed by setPoints.

lessons.title: a - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Hooks, such as useState, are crucial parts of React. They allow us to add features to components, making them more powerful and interactive.

Using them allows us to remember things. Such as if we have the light turned on or off.

lessons.title: a
lessons.interactiveContent:
By now, we've learned how to create a state variable using the useState hook and set an initial value.

Make sure to pick count followed by setCount and then setCount, count.

lessons.title: a - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
When using React, we're not limited to one state variable. We can have as many as we want.

Create a second state variable called growthPlant2 and set its initial value to 0.

Make sure to pick growthPlant2, followed by setGrowthPlant2, and finally 0.

lessons.title: a - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can decide the initial value. It can be anything we want.

Set the initial value of growthPlant1 to 10.

Make sure to pick 10.

lessons.title: a - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We're not limited to numbers when it comes to state variables.

Set up the useState hook and initialize the happiness variable with a string containing an emoji.

Make sure to pick useState followed by ( and then ":-)", ).

lessons.title: a - Copy - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Booleans can also be used for state variables.

Set the value false as the initial value of the state variable isLightOn. Also, ensure that toggleLight inverts the value of the variable.

Make sure to pick false, followed by !, and finally isLightOn.

lessons.title: Lesson #7 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Ensure to change the state variable stage in the advanceStage function the first time the button is clicked.

Make sure to pick setStage, followed by "Intermediate".

lessons.title: Lesson #7
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a state variable, gadgetPower.

Make sure to pick const followed by [ and then gadgetPower, ,, setGadgetPower, ], useState.

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
What value can we use for the initial state?

Every value0, "", and false

Every value.

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a boolean state variable isVisible with initial value true and toggle it.

Make sure to pick isVisible followed by setIsVisible and then useState, true.

lessons.title: Lesson #13
lessons.interactiveContent:
How many state variables can we use in one component?

As many as we want3 per component

As many as we want.

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create two separate states, heroName and heroPower.

Make sure to pick useState, followed by useState.

lessons.title: Lesson #13
lessons.interactiveContent:
Complete the code to create a state variable gameLevel initialized at 1.

Make sure to type useState.

lessons.title: Lesson #14
lessons.interactiveContent:
How do we import the useState hook?

import React, { useState } from "react"import React, useState from "react"

import React, { useState } from "react".

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
Update both state variables in the nextLevel function.

Make sure to pick setScore, followed by setStage.

We can use a non-state variable and render it.

However, when we update a variable that's also rendered, React doesn't update the HTML it displays.

Make sure to pick count, followed by count, and finally count.

count is a regular variable, not state, so React doesn’t re-render when count changes.

Try clicking the button and see how the console output shows the updated state, but the rendered HTML doesn't change.

Make sure to pick count, followed by +=, and finally 1.

lessons.title: a
lessons.interactiveContent:
To ensure React renders the updated HTML, we need to use the setter for the state variable.

Never update a state variable directly, but only through the setter.

Make sure to pick setCount followed by ( and then count + 1, ), ;.

lessons.title: a - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
State updates are asynchronous. When you call the setter function, React schedules the update but doesn’t apply it immediately.

If we use the updated state value right after calling the setter, it may still reflect the previous value.

Make sure to pick console.log, followed by count.

lessons.title: a - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We'll soon learn about another hook to observe state changes.

For now, remember that hooks, such as useState, run asynchronously. We can't know when the variable is updated and the HTML re-rendered.

Make sure to pick setCount, followed by setCount.

lessons.title: Lesson #7
lessons.interactiveContent:
What do we need to use to ensure React updates the HTML when a state variable changes?

useState hookRegular JavaScript variables

useState hook.

lessons.title: Lesson #6
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use the correct hook to declare a state variable.

Make sure to pick useState, followed by useState.

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which statement about state updates is correct?

State updates are asynchronousState updates are immediate

State updates are asynchronous.
